question_one.text: What are the objectives of the FAO Economics and Policy Innovations for Climate-Smart Agriculture (EPIC) Programme?

answers.text: The objectives of the FAO Economics and Policy Innovations for Climate-Smart Agriculture (EPIC) Programme are to close critical gaps in the knowledge of how to enhance and manage the trade-offs between food security, livelihood, and environmental goals in the face of a changing climate, develop and evaluate options for adapting to a changing climate to inform agricultural development, food security policy, and donor investment strategies, provide an evidence base for identifying, developing, and implementing practices, policies, and investments for climate-smart agriculture, develop a country-owned strategic framework to guide action and investment on CSA, formulate climate-smart agriculture investment proposals and identify possible financing sources, and build capacity to plan, implement, and finance climate-smart agriculture on the basis of the results above.

The objectives of the FAO Economics and Policy Innovations for Climate-Smart Agriculture (EPIC) Programme are to develop tools, knowledge, and partnerships to support countries in achieving climate-smart agriculture . The program works together with NOMAFSI to organize Climate Smart Agriculture (CSA) investment proposals and policy recommendations for Vietnam, based on future climate and socio-economic scenarios . The program aims to provide an evidence base for identifying, developing, and implementing practices, policies, and investments for climate-smart agriculture . Additionally, the program aims to build capacity to plan, implement, and finance climate-smart agriculture . Finally, the program aims to expand the evidence base produced through econometric analysis indicators of food security, mitigation, and adaptation by running simulations on these same indicators under the various scenarios identified .

question_two.text: What are the main challenges for the CGIAR Research Program on Climate Change, Agriculture and Food Security (CCAFS) in Southeast Asia?

answers.text: The critical challenges for CCAFS in Southeast Asia are associated with the increasingly complex and stressed agricultural landscape due to increasing climatic unpredictability, pollution, population, water supply and quality, energy, livelihoods, and issues around sustainability. The project aims to enable and assist farmers, policymakers, researchers, and donors to continually monitor, assess, and adjust their actions in response to observed and anticipated changes in climate. The project also aims to develop and evaluate options for adapting to a changing climate to inform agricultural development, food security policy, and donor investment strategies.

The main challenges for the CGIAR Research Program on Climate Change, Agriculture and Food Security (CCAFS) in Southeast Asia are associated with the increasingly complex and stressed agricultural landscape . Increasing climatic unpredictability exacerbates all pressures on the agricultural production systems of Southeast Asia . Food security is challenged by the low and dramatically falling cultivated land per capita, especially in the most productive areas of the region . To address these challenges, CCAFS has initiated activities in South Asia, East Africa, and West Africa . The program is collaborating with the International Center for Tropical Agriculture (CIAT) and all 15 CGIAR research centers, as well as with other CGIAR thematic research programs . The FAO Economics and Policy Innovations for Climate-Smart Agriculture (EPIC) Programme and the CCAFS are working together with NOMAFSI to organize Climate Smart Agriculture (CSA) investment proposals and policy recommendations for Vietnam, based on future climate and socio-economic scenarios . The FAO/CCAFS scenarios process has focused on contextual drivers of change for Climate Smart Agriculture â€“ climate change and socio-economic changes . In South East Asia, socio-economic and climate scenarios have been developed at the subcontinental level up to 2050 . To meaningfully assess the feasibility of Climate Smart Agriculture investment proposals, these have to be examined in the context of multiple scenarios representing diverse future socio-economic and climate developments .

question_three.text: How can scenarios be used as a policy tool for adaptation planning?

answers.text: Scenarios can be used as a policy tool for adaptation planning by representing multiple plausible directions that future drivers of change may take. Rather than attempting to forecast a single future, scenarios allow for the capturing of uncertainties and systems complexity in a coherent and plausible yet surprising and challenging fashion. The development and use of scenarios functions as a platform for the exchange and application of knowledge and experience between researchers and policy makers, private sectors, NGOs and other societal actors. Scenarios also allow for the capturing of uncertainties and systems complexity in a coherent and plausible yet surprising and challenging fashion. By using scenarios to test investment proposals, actors can engage in a dialogue about future uncertainties which results in an active, critical understanding of the proposals, and therefore leads to co-ownership of these plans and will make it more likely that they are truly informed by regional perspectives.

Scenarios can be used as a policy tool for adaptation planning by generating shared engagement, building relationships, commitments, and new ideas, which enhances adaptive capacity and sustainable policies . The development and use of scenarios can function as a platform for the exchange and application of knowledge and experience between researchers and policy makers, private sectors, NGOs, and other societal actors . Scenarios can be used to test investment proposals, engage actors in a dialogue about future uncertainties, and result in an active, critical understanding of the proposals, leading to co-ownership of these plans and making it more likely that they are truly informed by regional perspectives . Scenarios can also be used to contextualize drivers of change for Climate Smart Agriculture, such as climate change and socio-economic changes, and to develop and evaluate options for adapting to a changing climate to inform agricultural development, food security policy, and donor investment strategies  . Scenarios can be combined with multiple climate scenarios and vice versa, and can be used to review and revise Climate Smart Agriculture investment proposals for feasibility, discuss enabling policy conditions, and quantify through two global partial equilibrium models   .

Scenarios can be used as a policy tool for adaptation planning by representing multiple plausible directions that future drivers of change may take, allowing for the capturing of uncertainties and systems complexity in a coherent and plausible yet surprising and challenging fashion. Scenarios are an excellent tool for generating shared engagement, building relationships, commitments, and new ideas, building greater capacity for collaborative governance to enhance adaptive capacity and sustainable policies. The development and use of scenarios function as a platform for the exchange and application of knowledge and experience between researchers and policymakers, private sectors, NGOs, and other societal actors. Ultimately, using scenarios as a policy tool for adaptation planning can inform regional perspectives and increase the likelihood of informed and effective decision-making.
